questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a painful, irreducible groin hernia, severe colicky pain, bilious vomiting, and absence of faeces or flatus for 24 hours. The hernia is tense and extremely tender, with reddish-blue skin discolouration and no cough impulse. What is the immediate next step in management?

choices.text: Administer IV antibiotics and fluids and proceed with surgery
Immediate surgical repair with synthetic mesh
Apply cold compresses to the hernia to reduce swelling
Start oral antibiotics and monitor the hernia for changes

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Administer IV antibiotics and fluids and proceed with surgery

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation suggests a strangulated hernia, which requires urgent surgical intervention.
  • The immediate next step is to administer IV antibiotics and fluids and proceed with surgery.

 

Strangulated Hernia:

  • A strangulated hernia occurs when a portion of tissue or intestine protrudes through a weakened area in the abdominal wall and becomes trapped.
  • The trapped segment loses its blood supply, leading to tissue ischemia (lack of blood flow) and potential tissue death if not promptly treated.

Clinical Features:

  • Irreducibility: The hernia cannot be pushed back.
  • Signs of Intestinal Obstruction: Colicky pain, bilious vomiting, absence of faeces and flatus.
  • History: Sudden onset of pain at the hernia site, followed by generalised abdominal pain.
  • Physical Examination Findings: Tense, extremely tender hernia with reddish or bluish skin discolouration and no cough impulse.
  • Diagnosis is primarily based on clinical examination and physical findings.

 

Treatment:

  • Initial Resuscitation:
    • Administer intravenous (IV) fluids.
    • Provide IV antibiotics.
    • Perform nasogastric aspiration.
    • Insert Foley's catheter.
  • Surgical intervention is done only after Initial Resuscitation.


 

Surgical management Algorithm:

Mesh Usage:

  • Synthetic mesh is contraindicated due to the increased risk of infection.
  • If a mesh is necessary, bioprosthetic or absorbable mesh is preferred.

questions.text: A patient presents with an incisional hernia located just above the umbilicus in the midline of the abdomen. According to the EHS classification, how is this hernia classified?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) M3

 

Explanation:

  • In the EHS classification system, an incisional hernia located just above the umbilicus in the midline is classified as M3, which covers the area from 3 cm above to 3 cm below the umbilicus.
  • The classification divides incisional hernias into two main categories: Midline & Lateral.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT typically considered an indication for surgical repair of an umbilical hernia in adults?

choices.text: Incarceration or strangulation of hernia contents
Symptomatic hernia causing pain or discomfort
Hernia in a patient with a BMI of 32

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hernia in a patient with a BMI of 32

 

Explanation:

  • While obesity (BMI > 30) is a risk factor for hernia development and recurrence, the presence of a hernia in an obese patient is not, by itself, an absolute indication for surgical repair.
  • The decision to repair would depend on other factors such as hernia size, symptoms, and overall patient health.
  • Weight loss might be recommended before surgery to reduce operative risks and improve outcomes.

 

Important indications for umbilical hernia repair in adults:

  • Incarceration or strangulation (Option A ruled out): Requires immediate repair due to the risk of bowel necrosis.
  • Symptomatic hernias (Option C ruled out): Indicated when the hernia causes pain or discomfort.
  • Defects larger than 2 cm (Option B ruled out): Larger defects are more prone to complications.
  • Thinning of overlying skin: Increased risk of complications, such as skin breakdown or incarceration.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a feature associated with the image shown below?

choices.text: Covered by amnion and peritoneum layers
Higher incidence of associated chromosomal abnormalities like Trisomy 13, 18, and 21
The defect is usually located to the right of the umbilical cord insertion
Can be associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Defect is usually located to the right of the umbilical cord insertion

 

Explanation:

  • The image shows an Omphalocele, where the defect is situated in the midline of the abdomen, typically at or near the umbilical cord insertion.
  • In contrast, a defect located to the right of the umbilical cord insertion is indicative of Gastroschisis, not omphalocele.

 

Feature

Omphalocele

Gastroschisis

Definition

Congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal contents protrude through the base of the umbilicus.

Congenital abdominal wall defect where abdominal contents protrude through a defect typically located to the right of the umbilicus. (Option C)

Covering

The herniated organs are covered by two layers: Amnion (outer) and peritoneum (inner). (Option A ruled out)

No membrane covers the exposed organs.

Associated conditions
  • Chromosomal abnormalities: Associated with Trisomy 13, 18, and 21. (Option B ruled out)
  • Other congenital malformations affect multiple systems in the following order: cardiovascular> Muscular> gastrointestinal> genitourinary. (Mnemonic: "CM GIGU")
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome: Can include hemihypertrophy, macroglossia, visceromegaly, omphalocele, and increased risk of hepatoblastoma. (Option D ruled out)
  • Fewer chromosomal abnormalities compared to omphalocele.
  • Higher risk of intestinal atresia and dysfunction.

Prognosis

Generally poor due to associated congenital malformations, which are the most common cause of death.

Generally better than omphalocele due to fewer associated congenital anomalies.

questions.text: A 75-year-old thin woman presents with intermittent pain and paresthesia along the medial aspect of her right thigh. She reports nausea and vomiting over the past few days. On examination, hip flexion and external rotation exacerbate her thigh pain. Which of the following signs is most specific for the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Howship-Romberg sign

 

Explanation:

  • The presentation suggests an obturator hernia, which is diagnosed based on thigh pain exacerbated by hip flexion and external rotation.
  • The Howship-Romberg sign, specific for obturator hernia, involves pain along the medial thigh extending to the knee when the hip is flexed, adducted, and internally rotated, due to compression of the obturator nerve by the hernia.

 

Obturator hernia:

  • More common in thin and elderly females.
  • Symptoms:
    • Intermittent pain and paresthesia along the medial thigh (due to compression of the obturator nerve)
    • Nausea and vomiting (suggest possible bowel obstruction)
  • Physical examination:
    • Pain exacerbated by hip flexion and external rotation.
    • Howship - Romberg sign
    • Hannington - Kiff sign: Absence of obturator reflex.

Cough impulse (Option A) is more typical of inguinal or femoral hernias, where a bulge or impulse is felt when the patient coughs. Obturator hernias are usually not visible or palpable externally.

Carnett's Sign (Option C) is not specific to hernias but helps differentiate abdominal wall pain from intra-abdominal pain.

  • The examiner palpates a tender area while the patient tenses their abdominal muscles by lifting their head or legs.
  • Increased or unchanged pain suggests an abdominal wall origin; decreased pain points to an intra-abdominal source.

Murphy's sign (Option D) is specific for acute cholecystitis and unrelated to the hernia. The examiner places their hand below the right costal margin and asks the patient to take a deep breath. Pain and breath-holding during this manoeuvre indicate gallbladder inflammation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a painful lump in her lower right abdomen, lateral to the rectus muscle. The swelling becomes more prominent when she stands or coughs. CT scan shows a defect in the transversus abdominis aponeurosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Spigelian hernia

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario suggests a Spigelian hernia based on the lateral location of the swelling in the lower abdomen and a defect in the transversus abdominis aponeurosis seen on the CT scan.
  • AKA ‘lateral ventral hernia or a hernia of the semilunar line’.
  • It is the protrusion of preperitoneal fat, peritoneal sac, or organ(s) through a defect in the Spigelian fascia, which is the aponeurosis between the lateral edge of the rectus abdominis muscle medially and the semilunar line laterally.
  • Typically presents as a painful lump that becomes more prominent when standing or coughing, and can be prone to incarceration due to its location.
  • Surgical repair via an open or laparoscopic approach is recommended due to the high risk of complications.

 

Epigastric hernia (Option A) occurs in the midline between the xiphoid process and umbilicus, is usually small, and is often asymptomatic. It has no relation to the transversus abdominis aponeurosis.

 

Umbilical hernia (Option B) protrudes through the umbilicus, appearing as an outward bulge at the navel. This condition is more common in infants and obese adults, and its location at the umbilicus differs from the lateral abdominal wall.


An incisional hernia (Option D) occurs at the site of a previous surgical incision and requires a history of abdominal surgery. It can occur anywhere on the abdominal wall, not specifically related to the transversus aponeurosis

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with right lower abdominal swelling and is diagnosed with a sliding hernia. After discussing the risks, his surgery is planned for hernia repair. Which of the following statements regarding sliding hernia is true?

choices.text: More common in females than males
Anterior wall of the sac is formed by the viscera
There is an increased risk of bowel injury during management.
Most common content is the appendix.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) There is an increased risk of bowel injury during management.

 

Explanation:

Surgical management of sliding hernia is associated with increased risk of bowel injury because the posterior wall of the hernia sac is formed by the viscera, which are directly involved in the hernia.

 

Sliding hernia (Hernia-En-Glissade):

  • It occurs when a portion of the peritoneum that normally lines the abdominal cavity slides through the hernia defect, bringing a partially retroperitoneal organ.
  • More common in males, particularly the elderly (Option A ruled out) and frequently occurs on the left side, where the sigmoid colon is the most common content, not the appendix. (Option D ruled out)
  • The posterior wall of the hernia sac is formed by the viscera (commonly bowel), not the anterior wall. (Option B ruled out)
  • Clinical presentation:
    • Patients typically present with a reducible swelling in the groin or lower abdomen that worsens on standing due to gravity.
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms like constipation and incomplete bowel emptying are common, indicating bowel involvement.

Managed surgically by repairing or closing the defect, but associated with a higher risk of bowel injury due to the involvement of the viscera in the hernia sac.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a history of Gardner’s syndrome presents with persistent abdominal pain and a palpable mass in the left lower quadrant. She has previously undergone an open proctocolectomy. Imaging studies reveal an infiltrative mass in the mesentery. What is the most appropriate management strategy for her recurrent intra-abdominal mass?

choices.text: Immediate systemic chemotherapy without further surgical intervention.
Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin, potentially followed by radiotherapy.
Hormonal therapy to manage the tumor.
Laparoscopic surgery to remove the tumor, given its lower risk of recurrence.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin, potentially followed by radiotherapy.

 

Explanation:

  • The recurrent intra-abdominal mass is likely a Desmoid tumor, which is associated with Gardner’s syndrome and previous abdominal surgery.
  • These tumors are known for their infiltrative nature and aggressive growth.
  • Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin is recommended to effectively manage the tumor, often followed by radiotherapy to reduce the risk of recurrence.

 

Desmoid Tumor:

  • Most common primary malignant tumors of the mesentery.
  • Classified based on their location:
    • Extra-abdominal: 60%
    • Abdominal wall: 25%
    • Intra-abdominal: 50%
  • Risk Factors:
    • History of surgery or trauma
    • Estrogen: Estrogen stimulates tumor growth. Hence, more common in females.
    • Genetic Factors: A variant of FAP (Gardner's syndrome) increases the risk.
  • Characteristics:
    • Unencapsulated Nature: Prone to cracking during surgical excision.
    • No Distant Metastasis or Sarcomatous Change
  • Clinical Features:
    • Presentation: Most commonly presents as a palpable mass or lump.
    • Location: Commonly arises from musculoaponeurotic structures in the infra-umbilical region.
  • Diagnosis is best confirmed with a biopsy, and the extent of the disease is assessed using MRI.
  • Management:
    • Surgery: Wide local excision with a 2 cm margin is preferred.
    • Recurrent Tumors: Combination of surgery and radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a reducible swelling in the left groin below the inguinal ligament, suggesting a femoral hernia. The surgeon opts for a low approach to access the femoral canal directly without entering the inguinal canal. Which technique is most appropriate for this approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lockwood's technique

 

Explanation:

Lockwood's technique is a low approach that involves making an incision below the groin crease directly over the hernia. It provides excellent access to the femoral canal and is often considered the preferred method for femoral hernia repair due to its directness and effectiveness, particularly for uncomplicated cases.

Femoral Hernia:

A groin hernia occurs when abdominal contents, typically a portion of the intestine or fatty tissue, protrude through the femoral canal in the lower abdominal wall.

  • Location: Appears as a bulge in the upper thigh, just below the groin crease.
  • Demographics: More common in women, especially older and overweight females.
  • Risk: Higher risk of incarceration and strangulation compared to inguinal hernias.
  • Symptoms:
    • Lump in the groin or upper thigh, which may be painless or painful.
    • Discomfort when standing, lifting, or straining.
    • Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain if the hernia becomes incarcerated or strangulated.

 

  • Treatment Approaches:

Technique

Approach

Description

Lockwood's (Option A)

Open, Low

Incision below groin crease, directly over hernia; Elective repair

McEvedy's (Option B ruled out)

Open, High

Oblique incision above inguinal ligament

Lotheissen's (Option C ruled out)

Open, High

Access through the inguinal canal

Open

Suturing conjoint tendon to Cooper's ligament

TEP (Totally Extraperitoneal)

Mesh placement without entering the peritoneal cavity

questions.text: During laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair, which critical structure should the surgeon avoid to prevent significant bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Corona Mortis

 

Explanation:

The Corona mortis artery is the most critical structure to avoid during laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair because, if damaged, it can cause significant bleeding.

 

Corona mortis (Crown of Death):

  • Anatomical variant involving an abnormal connection between the External iliac artery and the Obturator artery.
  • Located behind the superior pubic ramus.
  • This variant is critical to identify during laparoscopic procedures because it can lead to severe and potentially life-threatening bleeding if damaged.

The Obturator artery (Option A) is a significant vessel supplying the medial compartment of the thigh. Although its injury can cause bleeding, it is typically well protected in laparoscopic procedures and usually not as prone to causing severe haemorrhage as the Corona Mortis.

 

The accessory Obturator Artery (Option B) is a variant of the obturator artery, less commonly encountered and associated with lower risk during laparoscopic procedures.

 

The Superficial Epigastric Artery (Option D) branches from the femoral artery, supplying the lower abdomen's skin. Its injury is less likely to cause severe haemorrhage and is less critical than Corona Mortis in laparoscopic procedures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with sudden groin pain and diarrhoea is found to have a small bulge in the right groin. She describes the pain as colicky and has symptoms resembling acute gastroenteritis. Which type of hernia is most likely associated with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Richter’s hernia

Explanation:

The given scenario with groin pain, diarrhoea, and a small bulge in the right groin with symptoms resembling gastroenteritis points toward Richter’s Hernia.

 

Hernia

Features

Images

Richter’s Hernia (Option D)
  • Herniation of only a portion of the bowel wall (circumference) into the hernia sac.
  • Leads to localized strangulation or incarceration of part of the bowel wall while the bowel lumen remains intact.
  • Mimics Gastroenteritis (Diarrhea, colicky pain) potentially delaying diagnosis and increasing the risk of complications like strangulation.

Seen in: (Narrow Defects)

  • Paraumbilical Hernia
  • Femoral Hernia
  • Obturator Hernia

Littre’s Hernia

(Option A)

It involves a Meckel’s diverticulum herniating into the sac.

Amyand’s Hernia

(Option B)

Contains the Appendix within the hernia sac.

Maydl’s Hernia

(Option C)
  • It involves two or more bowel loops that become incarcerated or strangulated within the hernia sac.
  • The obstructed loop is present intraperitoneally and hence, easily missed during surgery.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female presents with a non-reducible right groin bulge below the inguinal ligament, confirmed by ultrasound to extend into the femoral canal. According to the Gilbert classification, which type best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Type 7

 

Explanation:

The patient's hernia, located below the inguinal ligament and extending into the femoral canal, is classified as a Type 7 (Femoral hernia) according to the Gilbert classification.

 

Gilbert classification system for Groin Hernias:

 

Type 1: Indirect, small hernia (Option A ruled out)
  • A hernia that protrudes through the deep inguinal ring.
  • It is typically small and often seen in pediatric cases.

Type 2: Indirect, medium hernia
  • An indirect hernia that is larger than Type 1 but does not yet cause significant displacement of the surrounding structures.
  • Admits one finger but less than two-finger breadth.

Type 3: Indirect, large hernia (Option B ruled out)
  • A significant indirect hernia may extend into the scrotum or cause a more noticeable displacement of structures.
  • > 2 Finger breath

Type 4: Direct hernia, involves the entire floor
  • A direct hernia that protrudes through the weakened area of the abdominal wall (Hesselbach's triangle), involving the entire floor of the inguinal canal.
  • It has an intact internal ring.

Type 5: Direct hernia, diverticular
  • A direct hernia where the sac resembles a diverticulum.
  • It has an intact internal ring.

Type 6: Combined hernia (Romberg's hernia)

(Option C ruled out)

It involves both direct and indirect components, often referred to as a pantaloon or saddleback hernia.

Type 7: Femoral hernia

(Option D)
  • A hernia that protrudes through the femoral canal, located below the inguinal ligament.
  • It is less common and more prone to complications like strangulation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male has a right groin bulge that worsens with standing and reduces when lying down. The bulge is medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Based on the Nyhus classification, which type of hernia does this patient have?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Type III A

 

Explanation:

The given scenario points towards Direct Inguinal Hernia, as the bulge is medial to inferior epigastric vessels and is due to the posterior wall defect. It is classified as Type III A under the NYHUS Classification.

 

NYHUS Classification:

Type I

Indirect inguinal hernia (Option A ruled out)

  • Normal internal inguinal ring

e.g., pediatric hernia

Type II

Indirect inguinal hernia (Option B ruled out)

  • Dilated internal inguinal ring
  • Posterior inguinal wall intact

Type III

A: Direct inguinal hernia (Option C)

B: Indirect inguinal hernia (Option D ruled out)

  • Internal inguinal ring dilated
  • Encroaching medially or destroying the transversalis fascia of the Hesselbach triangle (e.g. scrotal sliding or pantaloon hernia)

C: Femoral hernia

Type IV (Recurrent Hernia)

A: Direct

B: Indirect

C: Femoral

D: Combined

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) and presents with severe respiratory distress. Physical examination revealed a scaphoid abdomen and a chest X-ray showed bowel loops in the thoracic cavity and a mediastinal shift. What is the most appropriate initial intervention to stabilise the infant before surgical repair?

choices.text: Bag-mask ventilation to ensure adequate oxygenation.
Placement of an Orogastric tube to decompress the stomach
IV Antibiotics to prevent infection in the herniated bowel.
Immediate surgery, irrespective of the status

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Placement of an Orogastric tube to decompress the stomach

 

Explanation:

  • The placement of an orogastric tube is essential to decompress the stomach, reduce pressure on the lungs, and alleviate respiratory distress and mediastinal shift, helping to stabilize the infant before surgical repair.
  • Repair is done only after pulmonary stabilization in CDH (Immediate surgery done in case of traumatic hernia)

 

Management of Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia:

  • Initial Stabilization:
    • Airway Management: Immediate endotracheal intubation is critical.
      • Ventilation of Choice: IPPV
      • If there is no response → ECMO
    • Avoid excessive, mean airway pressure to prevent barotrauma
    • Gastric Decompression: An orogastric tube is used to prevent gastric distention that worsens lung compression.
    • Bag and Mask Ventilation is Contraindicated in CDH (Option A)

 

  • Pulmonary Hypertension Management:
    • Medications: Nitric oxide, prostaglandin E1, milrinone, and inotropes for cardiac dysfunction.
    • Severe Cases: Extracorporeal Life Support (ECLS) may be required.

 

  • Surgical Repair:
    • Timing: Repair is performed once pulmonary circulation stabilizes. (Option D)
    • For Small Defects: Sutures.
    • For large defects, use a conical silastic or GOR-TEX patch.

 

IV Antibiotics to prevent infection in the herniated bowel (Option C), While antibiotics may be administered as part of the overall management, they are not the primary intervention for immediate stabilization of the infant.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with abdominal pain and intermittent nausea. Physical examination reveals a large, non-tender abdominal mass in the left lower quadrant, contiguous with the small intestine in the mesentery. Based on the findings, which type of mesenteric cyst is most likely, and what is the preferred management approach?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Enterogenous cyst - Resection and anastomosis

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and imaging findings of a large, well-defined cystic lesion with thickened walls and contiguous with the small intestine are most consistent with an Enterogenous cyst.
  • The preferred management for this type of cyst is resection and anastomosis due to its connection with the bowel.

 

Mesenteric Cysts:

  • Rare abdominal masses that originate in the mesentery, the fold of tissue connecting the intestines to the abdominal wall.
  • They can vary in size and type and are generally categorized based on their origin and content.
  • Types:
    • Chylolymphatic
    • Enterogenous
    • Traumatic
    • Hydatid
  • Often asymptomatic but can present with abdominal pain, vomiting, torsion, rupture, or infection.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Ultrasound: Initial imaging modality used to assess the cyst’s characteristics.
    • Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) is the investigation of choice.

Features

Chylolymphatic (Option B)

Enterogenous (Option A)

Origin

Arises from congenitally misplaced lymphatic tissue.

Derived from a diverticulum or duplication of the intestine.

Location

Mesentery of the ileum.

Mesentery of the small intestine.

Wall Characteristic

Thinner wall, composed of connective tissue.

Thicker wall, lined by mucous membrane

Fluid

Clear lymph or chyle
  • Mucinous fluid
  • Colorless or yellowish brown.

Blood supply

Independent blood supply.

Shares a blood supply with the adjacent bowel.

Management

Enucleation

Resection of the cyst and affected bowel segment.

Transillumination

Transillumination (-ve)

Transillumination (+ve)
 

 

Hydatid cysts (Option C), caused by echinococcal infection, typically present as cystic lesions in the liver or lungs but can also occur in the mesentery. They are managed with antiparasitic therapy, but this diagnosis is less likely due to the usual homogeneous appearance and less internal complexity on imaging.

 

Traumatic cysts (Option D) typically follow recent abdominal trauma, appearing as cystic structures with heterogeneous contents, especially if hemorrhage or clot is present. They often have irregular margins and may show signs of inflammation or surrounding oedema.

questions.text: A day-old preterm infant is admitted with severe respiratory distress. Physical examination shows a scaphoid abdomen and chest X-rays reveal bowel loops in the thorax and a mediastinal shift. Despite intensive care, the infant's condition deteriorates rapidly and leads to death. Which of the following accurately describes a characteristic feature of the most common type of this condition?

choices.text: Left-sided posteromedial defect with herniation of small intestine
Right-sided anterolateral defect associated with herniation of the liver
Defective central tendon of the diaphragm
Failure of development of the pleuroperitoneal canal

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Failure of development of the pleuroperitoneal canal.

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of a preterm with respiratory distress, scaphoid abdomen, and X-ray showing bowel loops in the thorax points towards Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia (CDH)
  • CDH is a birth defect with an abnormal opening in the diaphragm, allowing abdominal organs to move into the chest cavity and severely impair lung development.
  • Most Common Side: Left (84%) > Right
  • It is of two types:
    • Bochdalek hernia is the most common type of CDH and is due to the failure of the development of the pleuroperitoneal canal. (Option D)
    • Morgagni Hernia is due to the defective Central tendon (Option C)

 

Feature

Bochdalek Hernia

Morgagni Hernia

Side

Left-sided

Right-sided

Location

Posterolateral

Anteromedial

Herniated Organs

Small intestine, stomach

Transverse colon, sometimes liver

Common Symptoms

Scaphoid abdomen, respiratory distress, mediastinal shift

Mostly Asymptomatic and Incidental

Diagnostic Features
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Pulmonary hypertension

Less severe respiratory distress

Association

Polyhydramnios, abnormal LHR, and liver position

Rarely detected prenatally; usually diagnosed later

Management

Variable

Generally Better prognosis

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male with chronic bronchitis, smoking history, and recent steroid use presents with a lower abdominal bulge that worsens with prolonged standing and heavy weight lifting. Which of these factors contributes to the risk of his condition?

 


	Chronic bronchitis
	Heavy weight lifting
	Smoking
	Steroid use
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

All listed factors are known risk factors for developing abdominal wall hernias.

 

Hernia is an abnormal protrusion of an organ or tissue through an opening in the abdominal wall or cavity.

 

Risk factors:

  • Increased Abdominal Pressure:
    • Chronic Cough (Chronic bronchitis) (Option A)
    • Heavy weight Lifting (Option B)
    • Obesity (Excess weight increases intra-abdominal pressure)
    • Pregnancy (The expanding uterus increases pressure and stress on the abdominal wall).
    • Chronic Constipation
    • Ascites
    • Obstructive uropathy (BPH / Stricture urethra)

 

  • Weak Connective Tissue:
    • Genetic Conditions: Collagen disorders like Ehlers-Danlos syndrome affect tissue strength and repair.
    • Smoking (Option C): Impairs collagen maturation and healing, contributing to hernia development.
    • Steroid intake also impairs wound healing and weakens tissues (Option D).

 

  • Aging: Age-related weakening of muscles and connective tissue increases susceptibility.

 

Predisposing factors:

Areas of Natural Weaknesses
  • Lumbar triangles
  • Inguinal Canal
  • Oesophageal hiatus, umbilical cicatrix

Developmental Abnormalities

Failure of Closure:

  • Patent processus vaginalis

Congenital Hernias:

  • Morgagni and Bochdalek hernias

Injury and Surgery
  • Surgical Incisions: weakened muscle strength at the site of incision
  • Traumatic Injuries

questions.text: Which technique of incisional hernia is done at point B?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inlay

 

Explanation:

The inlay technique is characterized by placing the mesh within the defect and suturing it to the fascial edges.

Incisional Hernia Mesh Placement Techniques:

Technique

Mesh Placement

Procedure

Advantages

Disadvantages

Inlay

(Option B)

Within the fascial defect itself

Mesh is sutured to the edges of the fascial defect.

It can be used for large defects where primary closure isn't possible.

High recurrence rates due to mesh separation from fascial edges under abdominal pressure

Onlay

(Option A)

On top of the anterior rectus sheath/external oblique aponeurosis

Subcutaneous tissue is dissected off; the fascial defect is closed primarily, and the mesh is placed on top and secured

Technically easier and less invasive.

Higher risk of seroma formation, mesh infection, and skin necrosis.

Retromuscular

(Option C)

Behind the rectus muscle but anterior to the posterior rectus sheath

The posterior rectus sheath is opened, the mesh is placed in the created space, and the posterior sheath is closed over it

Lower recurrence rates, mesh well incorporated into tissues

More complex procedure, risk of injury to neurovascular bundles.

Preperitoneal

(Option D)

Between the peritoneum and the posterior rectus sheath.

Peritoneum is separated from posterior rectus sheath, mesh is placed in this space, peritoneum is closed over it.

Good mesh incorporation, lower risk of adhesions.

Technically challenging, risk of peritoneal tears.

questions.text: Which type of lumbar hernia is characterized by a protrusion just below the 12th rib?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Grynfeltt-Lesshaft hernia

 

Explanation:

  • The Grynfeltt-Lesshaft hernia, also known as the superior lumbar hernia, occurs in the superior lumbar triangle, located just below the 12th rib.
  • This hernia is characterised by a protrusion through a weakness in the posterior abdominal wall in this specific area.

Petit's lumbar hernia (Option A) occurs through the inferior lumbar triangle, bounded by the iliac crest, external oblique, and latissimus dorsi muscles. It typically appears as a bulge in the lower back, above the iliac crest, and is less common than the Grynfeltt-Lesshaft hernia.

 

Gibbon's hernia (Option C) is not a type of lumbar hernia but refers to a parastomal hernia, which occurs around a stoma (an artificial abdominal opening for colostomy, ileostomy, or urostomy). It typically presents as a bulge around the stoma site.

 

Pantaloon hernia (Option D) is not a lumbar hernia but a type of inguinal hernia where the sac protrudes on both sides of the inferior epigastric vessels, resembling pantaloons. The hernia sac straddles the inferior epigastric vessels and contains both direct and indirect components.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a small, reducible swelling in her right groin area. Upon examination, you noticed that the swelling was located lateral to the femoral vessels. Which variant of femoral hernia is this most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Narath's hernia

 

Explanation:

The type of femoral hernia commonly associated with congenital hip dislocation is known as Narath's hernia.

 

Variants of femoral hernia:

Variant

Location

Characteristics

Narath's hernia

(Option A)

Lateral to femoral vessels
  • Also known as Lateral femoral hernia.
  • Protrudes through the defect in the fascia lateral to the femoral vein.
  • Associated with congenital hip dislocation.

Cloquet's hernia (Option B ruled out)

Behind femoral vessels
  • Also known as pectineal hernia
  • Extends through the defect in the pectineal fascia.
  • Lies posterior to femoral vein.

Velpeau's hernia (Option C ruled out)

In front of femoral vessels
  • Anterior femoral hernia.
  • Protrudes through fascia covering femoral sheath.
  • Lies anterior to femoral vessels.

Laugier's hernia (Option D ruled out)

Through Gimbernat's ligament
  • Also known as lacunar hernia.
  • Protrudes through the defect in the lacunar ligament.

Serafini's hernia

Through iliopectineal fascia
  • Hernia sac passes between the iliac vein and the pubic bone.
  • It can be mistaken for an obturator hernia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man undergoes emergency inguinal hernia surgery. Postoperatively, he experiences persistent groin pain, raising concerns about nerve injury. Which nerve is most commonly injured during open inguinal hernia surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Ilioinguinal nerve

Explanation:

The most commonly injured nerve during open inguinal hernia surgery is the ilioinguinal nerve, often leading to chronic pain as a complication.

 

  • The most common nerve injured in:
    • Open repair: Ilio-inguinal > Iliohypogastric > Genital branch of Genitofemoral nerve.
    • Laparoscopy: Lateral Cutaneous nerve of thigh > Genito-femoral nerve.

 

  • Landmarks in Laparoscopic Surgery:
    • Triangle of Doom: Injury to Iliac vessels
    • Triangle of Pain: Injury to Nerves causing postoperative pain

 

Complications of Surgery:

  • Immediate Complications:
    • Bleeding/Hematoma: From subcutaneous or inferior epigastric vessels.
    • Urinary Retention: May require catheterization.
    • Femoral Nerve Blockade

 

  • Early Postoperative Issues (within the first week):
    • Pain, Bruising, Swelling: Common.
    • Seroma Formation: Often resolves spontaneously; may need aspiration.
    • Wound Infection: Less frequent; routine antibiotics not recommended.
    • Testicular Infarction: Damage to the testicular artery during dissection or repair.

 

  • Long-term Concerns:
    • Chronic Pain:
      • Nerve Injury: Damage to nerves such as the ilioinguinal or iliohypogastric nerves during surgery.
      • Nerve Irritation: Chronic irritation by suture material or mesh.
      • Psychological Factors
    • Hernia Recurrence: Inadequate repair or weakness in the abdominal wall; mesh-related issues may also contribute.

questions.text: A laparoscopic surgeon is repairing an inguinal hernia and wants to avoid using electrocautery in certain areas to prevent injury. Which anatomical region should the surgeon avoid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Triangle of Pain

 

Explanation:

Triangle of Pain contains nerves (such as the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve and the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh), and using electrocautery here can lead to nerve damage, resulting in chronic pain or numbness.

Triangle of Doom (Option A)

Triangle of Pain (Option B)

Boundaries:

  • Medial: Vas deferens
  • Lateral: Gonadal vessels
  • Base: Fold of peritoneum
  • Apex: Deep inguinal ring

Boundaries:

  • Medial: Gonadal vessels
  • Lateral: Fold of peritoneum
  • Superior: Iliopubic tract

Content:

Iliac vessels are located behind the peritoneal fold.

Content: (Medial to Lateral)

  • Femoral nerve
  • Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve
  • Anterior cutaneous nerve of the thigh
  • Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh

Clinical Significance:

Sharp dissection in this area risks damaging the iliac vessels, which can lead to severe bleeding and potentially life-threatening complications

Clinical Significance:

  • Potential risk of nerve damage if electrocautery is used.
  • The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is the most commonly injured nerve.


 

Triangle of Hasselbach (Option C) is defined by the medial border of the inferior epigastric vessels, the lateral border of the rectus abdominis muscle, and the inguinal ligament inferiorly.It is primarily associated with inguinal hernias and is not specifically related to electrocautery hazards.

 

Triangle of Scarpa (Option D), also known as the femoral triangle, is bordered by the inguinal ligament, sartorius muscle, and the adductor longus muscle.

It identifies structures related to femoral vessels and nerves but is not the primary concern for electrocautery-related nerve injury in laparoscopic surgery.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with a progressively worsening right groin bulge over 6 months, causing discomfort during lifting or prolonged standing. The hernia is reducible, and he is scheduled for elective repair. What is the gold standard surgical technique for his inguinal hernia repair?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lichtenstein Repair

 

Explanation:

  • The Lichtenstein repair is recognised as the gold standard for inguinal hernia surgery due to its tension-free approach using synthetic mesh.
  • This technique is associated with low recurrence rates and favorable outcomes.

 

Management of Inguinal Hernia:

Surgical Approaches:

  • Herniotomy: (Option C ruled out)
    • It involves excising and closing the hernia sac
    • Primarily used in children with lateral hernias and congenital hydrocele.
    • In adults, herniotomy alone is insufficient due to high recurrence rates.
  • Hernioplasty: Includes herniotomy plus inguinal floor reconstruction with mesh.
  • Herniorrhaphy:
    • Includes herniotomy plus reconstruction of the inguinal floor with sutures
    • Techniques:

Bassini's Repair:

  • Involves suturing the internal oblique, transversus abdominis, and fascia transversalis to the inguinal ligament. Known as a triple-layer repair.
  • Higher recurrence rates.

Shouldice Repair: (Option A) involves a four-layer repair (double breasting of fascia transversalis), resulting in lower recurrence rates compared to Bassini's.

Modified Shouldice: A six-layer repair, including additional layers for reinforcement.

  

 

Anterior Tension-Free Repair:

  • Lichtenstein Repair: Utilizes a mesh to reinforce the inguinal floor, which is considered the gold standard due to lower recurrence rates and faster recovery.

Open Preperitoneal Repair:

  • Stoppa Repair: (Option D)
    • Uses a mesh to reinforce the area behind the peritoneum
    • Done in Recurrent inguinal hernia

Laparoscopic Hernia Repair:

  • Totally Extraperitoneal (TEP) Repair
  • Transabdominal Preperitoneal (TAPP) Repair


 

TEP

TAPP

Procedure

Surgery done above the peritoneum

Surgery done beneath the peritoneum

Advantages
  • Lower risk of bowel injury and peritoneal complications.
  • Reduced risk of adhesions.
  • Larger working space
  • Better visualisation

Disadvantages

Smaller working spaces can make the procedure more technically challenging.
  • A higher risk of bowel injury and adhesion formation due to entry into the peritoneal cavity.
  • Potential for increased postoperative pain compared to TEP.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presents with a gradually increasing bulge in his right groin, which becomes more prominent when standing and straining and can be reduced when lying down. The bulge is medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. Which statement best describes this inguinal condition?

choices.text: Direct hernia, passing through a defect in the abdominal wall.
Indirect hernia, passing through the deep inguinal ring into the scrotum.
Direct hernia, passing through the deep inguinal ring.
Indirect hernia, passing through a defect in the abdominal wall.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Direct hernia, passing through a defect in the abdominal wall

 

Explanation:

The medial bulge to the inferior epigastric vessels indicates a direct inguinal hernia, which protrudes through a weakness in the abdominal wall at Hesselbach's triangle.

 

Types of Inguinal Hernia:

Inguinal Hernia is a condition where the viscus protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal wall (Direct inguinal hernia) or inguinal canal in the groin area (Indirect inguinal hernia).

Feature

Indirect Inguinal Hernia

Direct Inguinal Hernia

Common in

Young adults

Elderly

Course

It enters through the deep inguinal ring, traverses the inguinal canal, and exits via the superficial inguinal ring.

Protrudes directly through Hesselbach's triangle

Relation to Spermatic Cord

Anterolateral to the spermatic cord

Posterior to the spermatic cord

Location of Neck of Sac

Above and medial to the pubic tubercle.

Lies within the Hesselbach's triangle.

Relation to Inferior Epigastric vessels

Lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Medial to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Relation to Scrotum

Descends into the scrotum

Does not Descend

Types
  • Bubonocele: Confined to inguinal canal
  • Funicular: Processus vaginalis closed above epididymis, hernia content distinct from testis
  • Complete/Scrotal: Testis in the lower part of the hernia

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with a bulge in his lower abdomen that worsens with heavy lifting or coughing. Physical examination reveals a direct inguinal hernia. Which of the following correctly describes the boundaries of the involved anatomical triangle?

choices.text: Lateral: Inferior epigastric vessels; Medial: Rectus abdominis; Inferior: Inguinal ligament
Lateral: Rectus abdominis; Medial: Inguinal ligament; Inferior: Femoral vessels
Lateral: Femoral vessels; Medial: Rectus abdominis; Inferior: Superior epigastric vessels
Lateral: Inguinal ligament; Medial: Femoral vessels; Inferior: Rectus abdominis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lateral: Inferior epigastric vessels; Medial: Rectus abdominis; Inferior: Inguinal ligament

 

Explanation:

The given scenario suggests a Direct inguinal hernia, and Hesselbach’s triangle is associated with it.

 

Hesselbach’s Triangle:

  • Weak spot in the abdominal wall is where direct inguinal hernias occur.
  • Covered only by the transversalis fascia and external oblique aponeurosis.
  • Susceptible to herniation, especially in elderly patients or those with increased abdominal pressure.
  • Boundaries:
    • Lateral border: Inferior epigastric vessels
    • Medial border: Rectus abdominis muscle
    • Inferior border: Inguinal ligament (Poupart’s ligament)
